Example

Sketch the graphs of \( f_1(x) = \sqrt{1 - x^2} \) and \( f_2(x) = - \sqrt{1 - x^2} \).

Solution

Since \(x^2 + y^2 = 1\) is the well-known equation of the circle with centre at the origin and radius \(1\), it follows that the graphs of \(f_1(x)\) and \(f_2(x)\) are the upper and lower halves of this circle.


Sometimes it is difficult or even impossible to solve an equation in \(x\) and \(y\) to obtain \(y\) explicitly in terms of \(x\).

Examples where explicit expressions for \(y\) cannot be obtained are \[\sin(xy) = y\] and \[x^2 + \sin y = 2y.\]
